author: By Alex Traub
title: Jack Anderson, Longtime Dance Critic for The Times, Dies at 88
description: He brought an all-embracing enthusiasm to about 4,000 articles for The New York Times on modern dance, tap, ballet and practically every other genre.
content: Jack Anderson, a writer on dance for The New York Times for about five decades who combined a historian’s learnedness with an enthusiast’s ardor for what was new and surprising, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections Companion, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: U.S. Sends More Missile Defense Systems to Middle East
description: The latest deployment is in response to growing threats from Iran and its allies in the region. President Biden has warned Iran to not join the war against Hamas.
content: The U.S. military said it would send more missile defense systems to the Middle East in response to “escalations” from Iran and its allies, who have threatened a broader war in the region. The deployment comes as Israel continues to signal intentions to invade Gaza after Hamas’s deadly incursion earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Horn
title: Why Jews Cannot Stop Shaking Right Now
description: The reverberations of pogroms past are shaping the reaction of Jews to Hamas’s attacks on Israel.
content: There is a reason so many Jews cannot stop shaking right now. The concept of intergenerational trauma doesn’t begin to describe the dark place into which this month’s attack plunged Jewish communities around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Escoffery
title: New Stories Put a Complicated Spin on Familiar Traumas
description: Collections by Vauhini Vara, Shannon Sanders and LaToya Watkins feature characters caught in the challenges and contradictions of being alive.
content: The journalist and author Vauhini Vara follows up her debut novel, “The Immortal King Rao,” with THIS IS SALVAGED: Stories (Norton, 185 pp., $26.95), a dazzling collection full of spellbinding prose and intimate glimpses into the minds of people grappling with life’s familiar but lesser-discussed traumas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Raja Abdulrahim, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
title: Israelis and Gazans Flee Amid Clashes and Warnings of Wider Regional War
description: Violence on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, and strikes in Syria and the West Bank, sent shock waves through the Middle East.
content: As Israeli forces massed along the border with Gaza on Sunday ahead of an expected ground invasion, escalating clashes on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, as well as strikes in Syria and in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, intensified fears of a widening regional conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: In Northern Gaza, the Price of a Ride South Is Out of Reach for Many
description: Israel continues to ramp up its calls for Gazans to evacuate, but the trip can cost hundreds of dollars, up from $3 a person before the war.
content: As Israel’s military ramped up its warnings for civilians to flee northern Gaza, many people there said that doing so was not an option because of cost — and that it was no guarantee of safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater
title: Meet the Republicans Running for Speaker
description: The lawmakers vying for the job include veterans of the House, committee chairmen, a top member of Republican leadership and a sophomore.
content: Nine Republicans have announced that they will run for speaker, after the party cast aside Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio as its latest nominee for the leadership post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: A ‘Rodelinda’ Brings Promise of Handel on the Hudson
description: R.B. Schlather’s new staging of this opera, with the excellent musicians of Ruckus, is the first of several Handel productions at Hudson Hall.
content: Huge if true, as they say: The new production of Handel’s “Rodelinda” that opened on Friday at Hudson Hall is just the first in a series of annual Handel stagings there to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Betsy Rawls, Winner of Eight Golf Majors, Dies at 95
description: With a strong short game, she won four Women’s opens and a total of 55 L.P.G.A. Tour events between 1951 and 1972. She also had leadership roles with the tour.
content: Betsy Rawls, who won eight major golf championships, including four United States Women’s Opens, in the first two decades of the L.P.G.A. Tour, and as an executive and tournament director helped propel the arrival of the women’s pro circuit as a big-money attraction, died on Saturday at her home in Lewes, Del. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Missile Strike Kills Six Workers at Postal Depot, Ukraine Says
description: The facility, on the outskirts of the eastern city of Kharkiv, was far from the front line but only about 20 miles from Russia’s border.
content: A missile slammed into a postal depot overnight on the outskirts of Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv, killing six workers and wounding at least 16 other employees, the Ukrainian authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: A President, a Billionaire and Questions About Access and National Security
description: Anthony Pratt, one of Australia’s wealthiest men, made his way into Donald Trump’s inner circle with money and flattery. What he heard there has become of interest to federal prosecutors.
content: The 2020 presidential campaign was underway, and Anthony Pratt was doubling down on Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: A Professional Pumpkin Carver Spills His Guts
description: Adam Bierton is allergic to pumpkins, but that doesn’t stop him from carving dozens each fall, the most of intricate of which can cost $5,000.
content: A group of children watched as Adam Bierton made his first few slashes into the meat of a pumpkin at the New York Botanical Garden earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For the Future of Maui, Native Hawaiians Push for Honoring Its Past
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 22, 2023.
content: “There’s this growing sentiment that Native Hawaiians are actually really sick and tired of listening to stories about the banyan tree.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Israeli Reservist From Maryland Is Killed Near Lebanon Border
description: Omer Balva, 22, was among the 360,000 reservists Israel had mobilized. He was near Israel’s northern border when his unit was struck by anti-tank missile fire, the Israeli military said.
content: An Israeli military reservist who was raised in Maryland was killed on Friday when anti-tank missile fire struck his unit near Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, the Israeli military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At the Met, a Refurbished ‘Bohème’ and an Art Deco ‘Ballo’
description: A gift from a board member recently paid for the company to rebuild sets for Franco Zeffirelli’s deathless 1981 production of Puccini’s classic.
content: If you go to “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera this season and are convinced that the big snowdrift in Act III looks a little fresher than usual, you’re not hallucinating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Urbina
title: A Brief History of a Problematic Appetizer
description: If you buy squid at a supermarket or what’s advertised as locally caught calamari in a restaurant, that food is part of a complicated story.
content: Americans didn’t always have an appetite for squid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Philadelphia Orchestra and Musicians Reach Contract Deal
description: The agreement, which includes salary increases of nearly 16 percent over three years, ends months of tense negotiations.
content: After months of wrangling at the negotiating table, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the union representing its musicians have reached a deal for a new contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Liao
title: With Bamboo and Jade, Silkpunk Rebuilds History
description: The Chinese video game Honkai: Star Rail borrows from an emerging literary subgenre that imagines modern worlds founded on East Asian traditions.
content: The floating ships in the fantasy role-playing game Honkai: Star Rail are populated with traders, gourmets and literati who surf their texts on jade abacuses. The game, from the Chinese company miHoYo, combines a taste of the Qing dynasty with gifts of the digital age — holographic bonsai and teleportation gateways for instant travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: From ‘Goodfellas’ to ‘Flower Moon’: How Scorsese Has Rethought Violence
description: The director was long identified with ornately edited set pieces. In “The Irishman” and his latest film, the flourishes have given way to blunt truths.
content: Of all the haunting images and disturbing sounds that permeate Martin Scorsese’s “Killers of the Flower Moon,” none is more upsetting than the guttural cry from Mollie Burkhart (Lily Gladstone), a tortured wail of rage and grief that escapes her reserved visage when tragedy strikes. And it often does: “Killers” tells the true story, adapted from the book by David Grann, of how Mollie’s Osage community was decimated by murderous white men, who killed dozens of her tribe members for rights to their oil-rich land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
title: Three Weapons That Israel and Ukraine Both Need From the U.S.
description: Ukraine and Israel are fighting different kinds of wars, but some weapons systems could soon be in short supply if the fighting continues for months.
content: With his prime-time vow to send more weapons to both Ukraine and Israel, President Biden sought to make clear on Thursday that the United States was not prioritizing one war over the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 23, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Worst Scandal in American Higher Education Isn’t in the Ivy League
description: Liberty University’s misconduct is emblematic of the crisis engulfing Christian America.
content: Those of us who write about higher education can pay too much attention to America’s elite universities. Schools like Harvard, Yale and Stanford are seen as virtual cultural superpowers, and the battle over these schools is sometimes seen as a proxy for battles over the future of the country itself. It’s not that this argument is wrong, exactly. That’s why I’ve written about these schools myself. But it’s incomplete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Strong First Weekend for ‘Killers,’ but Taylor Swift Was Still No. 1
description: The Scorsese film’s estimated $23 million in the North American box office was a special feat considering its length and the lack of promotion by its actors.
content: Martin Scorsese’s “Killers of the Flower Moon” opened this weekend in over 3,600 theaters, taking in an estimated $23 million in the United States and Canada. It’s the largest box office opening for the director since the $41.4 million opening for “Shutter Island” in February 2010 (starring Leonardo DiCaprio) and a special feat considering both its length — three and a half hours — and the lack of promotional support from its cast, which includes Mr. DiCaprio and Robert De Niro, because of the actors’ strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Inside the Commando Raids Unnerving Russia in Crimea
description: The lightning assaults are part of a larger campaign using drones and missiles to degrade Russian forces and demoralize the public.
content: Late one evening this month, two Ukrainian commandos eased into a side street in Kyiv in a battered SUV. Back from a dangerous nighttime assault on Russian positions in the Crimean Peninsula, they slipped into a sparsely furnished apartment where they sat at desks, weary and a little disheveled, and described their latest operation in matter-of-fact fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘While He Waited, He Turned His Gaze in Our Direction’
description: An encounter with André Watts, a holiday invitation from a cabby and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: The Spirited History of ‘Ghost’
description: ‘Ghost’ is a word that won’t soon fade from the pop-culture lexicon.
content: In 2015, the reporter Valeriya Safronova explained the new “ultimate silent treatment”: ghosting. To ghost someone, she wrote, was to end a romantic relationship “by cutting off all contact and ignoring the former partner’s attempts to reach out.” She cited examples: Charlize Theron had stopped answering Sean Penn’s calls and text messages. A man ghosted the woman he was dating for about eight months, leaving her to attend a wedding solo. Brutal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Israel Orders More Evacuations
description: Plus part one of our series, India’s Daughters.
content: As conflict intensified on Israel’s border with Lebanon, Israeli authorities said they were expanding a state-funded evacuation plan to an additional 14 villages. Along with a rare airstrike on the West Bank, the fighting raised fears that the war could expand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lorgia García Peña
title: A Different Border Crisis Mirrors What’s Happening in the U.S.
description: The border closures reinforced the dangerous nativist Dominican talk the government has deployed to contain Haitian immigration.
content: Haiti and the Dominican Republic together make up the island of Hispaniola. These countries are linked by histories of colonialism, slavery, dictatorships and U.S. military interventions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: Martin Scorsese’s New Film
description: “Killers of the Flower Moon,” is in theaters this weekend.
content: It’s not your imagination: Movies really are getting longer. The average blockbuster now runs thirty minutes more than films did in the 1990s, a recent Economist survey found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: LinkedIn issues warning to a site shaming pro-Palestinian sentiment.
description: The site listed thousands of people and grouped them by their workplaces after they posted on the Israeli-Hamas conflict.
content: Online posts asking to “#PrayForPalestine.” Entreaties for peace. Pleas to “Free Gaza.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Ryan Patrick Hooper
title: No Evidence of Hate Crime Has Emerged in Killing of Synagogue Leader, Officials Say
description: Detroit authorities are working with the F.B.I. as the city mourns the death of Samantha Woll.
content: One day after the fatal stabbing of the leader of a synagogue in Detroit, authorities on Sunday said no evidence had emerged that suggested the killing was motivated by antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Venezuela Holds a Key Vote. Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: Ten opposition candidates are running to face off against President Nicolás Maduro next year. A center-right former legislator, María Corina Machado, is widely expected to win.
content: One million Venezuelans were expected to head to the polls on Sunday to elect an opposition candidate to face President Nicolás Maduro in presidential elections in 2024, a contest that could prove pivotal to the fate of a country that has endured a decade of economic crisis and authoritarian governance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Collects Nazi Memorabilia?
description: Responses to an essay about Nazi objects from World War II. Also: Partisanship in judges; schools run by the Defense Department; victims of the Triangle fire.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Tim Scott, Who Supports Aid to Israel and Ukraine, Opposes a Package With Both
description: The South Carolina senator and 2024 presidential candidate said a “longer process” was needed to determine how much aid to send to Ukraine, while Israel demanded immediate attention.
content: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina said on Sunday that he would not support a request from President Biden to package aid for Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan and funding for border security, even though he has endorsed U.S. spending for each of those purposes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Far-Right Candidate Heads to Runoff in Argentina Election
description: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian, performed worse than polls predicted and will face Sergio Massa, Argentina’s economy minister, next month.
content: After leading in the polls for months, Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian economist, tumbled to second place in Argentina’s election on Sunday, sending him to a runoff next month that will be an important test of strength for the global far-right movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L’ Welcomes Bad Bunny and Mick Jagger
description: Bad Bunny was the host and musical guest in an episode that included cameos from Jagger and Pedro Pascal.
content: The chaos surrounding efforts to choose a new speaker of the House may be less than ideal for the nation, but it’s practically a gift to “Saturday Night Live,” which satirized House Republicans’ political turmoil in an opening sketch this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Bad Habits
description: Stella Zawistowski makes tracks through time.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: George Santos Swore He’d Never Talk to Me. Then the Phone Rang.
description: Ending months of silence, the politician began an unusual dialogue with a reporter he had long avoided.
content: It was just after noon on an early September Saturday when the first call came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: The Race to Save Our Secrets From the Computers of the Future
description: Quantum technology could compromise our encryption systems. Can America replace them before it’s too late?
content: They call it Q-Day: the day when a quantum computer, one more powerful than any yet built, could shatter the world of privacy and security as we know it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Fast and Easy Focaccia for Just a Bit of Baking
description: There’s something about putting together a dough, about measuring and kneading and waiting on a rise, that allows you to get out of your head.
content: Good morning. How are you doing? I’m compelled to ask. These are not easy days we’re marking. The news is relentless and largely grim, and it’s sometimes difficult to imagine a way forward, toward happiness and grace. You’re not alone, if that’s your state of mind. You’re one of many, and the best thing you can do about it is to reach out to others with empathy, with kindness, just to check in, just to say hello.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Australia Says China Is Poised to Lift Punishing Wine Tariffs
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he would visit China and meet with Xi Jinping, another sign of a thaw in the countries’ once-icy relations.
content: Australia’s prime minister, Anthony Albanese, announced on Sunday that he would visit China early next month, meeting with its top leader, Xi Jinping. Such a visit would be the first by an Australian leader since 2016 and another sign of easing tensions between the two nations, along with the recent release of a detained Australian journalist and a breakthrough on talks aimed at removing staggering tariffs on Australian wine that China imposed three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Gallagher Shannon, Jack D'Isidoro, Pat McCusker, John Woo, Rowan Niemisto and Paul Pontious
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Genius Behind Hollywood’s Most Indelible Sets’
description: How Jack Fisk, the master production designer behind “Killers of the Flower Moon” and many other films, brings the past to life.
content: Kihekah Avenue cuts through the town of Pawhuska, Okla., roughly north to south, forming the only corridor you might call a “business district” in the town of 2,900. Standing in the middle is a small TV-and-appliance store called Hometown, which occupies a two-story brick building and hasn’t changed much in decades. Boards cover its second-story windows, and part of the sign above its awning is broken, leaving half the lettering intact, spelling “Home.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 22, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 22, 2023.
content: An article last Sunday about a global fertilizer shortage referred incorrectly to a fertilizer ingredient that moved from Canada to Nigeria for much of last year and cost $1,350 a ton. It is potash, not phosphate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: What Most American Schools Do Wrong
description: When teachers stay with their students longer, they can see beyond the surface and recognize the brilliance beneath.
content: Which country has the best education system? Since 2000, every three years, 15-year-olds in dozens of countries have taken the Program for International Student Assessment — a standardized test of math, reading and science skills. On the inaugural test, which focused on reading, the top country came as a big surprise: tiny Finland. Finnish students claimed victory again in 2003 (when the focus was on math) and 2006 (when it was on science), all while spending about the same time on homework per week as the typical teenager in Shanghai does in a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Why Olive Oil Is So Expensive Right Now
description: Prices have more than doubled as extreme weather hit crops in Spain, Italy and elsewhere. The upcoming harvest isn’t looking much better, so that drizzle of oil on your salad may remain costly.
content: There is something different lately about the olive oil Michelle Spangler buys, bottles and infuses with flavors like basil and blood orange for her store in Dallas. It’s not the taste but the cost: Global olive oil prices have soared to record levels, more than doubling over the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Drone Warfare Comes to Washington’s Opera Stage
description: “Grounded,” by Jeanine Tesori and George Brant, is premiering at Washington National Opera after attracting criticism over sponsorship.
content: Wearing combat boots and a U.S. Air Force flight suit, the mezzo-soprano Emily D’Angelo took her place onstage one recent morning and began to sing about war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: A Glimpse Into Spain’s Future, Where Water Comes by Truck, Not Tap
description: Residents of Pozoblanco and 22 other villages in the country’s south have had to get their drinking water from tankers since April, when the reservoir serving the area dried up.
content: It was 10 a.m. when the villagers, clutching empty plastic containers, lined up behind the tanker truck of drinking water. A cake shop owner arrived with four big jugs for his pastries. Workers from a retirement home carried two dozen bottles back on wheelchairs for their wards. And a mother of four loaded her trunk with fresh water to wash vegetables and cook pasta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Evacuates More Areas Near Lebanon Amid Clashes With Hezbollah
description: The evacuation of Israeli towns and villages on the borders of Lebanon and Gaza amid escalating clashes is likely the largest in the country’s 75-year history, a local Israeli official said.
content: The Israeli authorities said on Sunday that they would evacuate 14 more Israeli villages near the northern border with Lebanon amid escalating tit-for-tat clashes between Israeli forces and Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militia, that have raised concerns that the Israel-Hamas war could ignite other regional confrontations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Foxconn, Apple’s Manufacturer in China, Is Said to Be Under Tax Audit
description: Chinese state media outlets say the Taiwanese factory giant is under investigation in four provinces. The company said it treated legal compliance as a “fundamental principle.”
content: Foreign and local companies in China are increasingly the targets of tax audits and other regulatory reviews, as local governments try to steady their finances by collecting more revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Eric Schmitt, Michael D. Shear and Ronen Bergman
title: U.S. Advises Israel to Delay Gaza Invasion, Officials Say
description: The Biden administration has suggested that more time is needed for hostage negotiations, the delivery of aid to Palestinians and mapping out ways to avoid more civilian casualties.
content: The Biden administration has advised Israel to delay a ground invasion of Gaza, hoping to buy time for hostage negotiations and to allow more humanitarian aid to reach Palestinians in the sealed-off enclave, according to several U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Nashville Chief’s Son Is Sought in Shooting of Two Officers
description: Chief John Drake of the Metropolitan Nashville Police confirmed that his estranged son, John C. Drake Jr., was the suspect in the shooting of two police officers in La Vergne, Tenn., on Saturday.
content: The authorities in Tennessee were searching on Sunday for the estranged son of Nashville’s police chief, a day after the chief’s son was identified as the suspect in the shooting of two police officers outside a Dollar General store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Ozempic and Wegovy Don’t Cost What You Think They Do
description: Drug companies are making billions from a new class of in-demand weight-loss treatments. But the prices are not what they seem.
content: The problem is daunting: Powerful but expensive new drugs could help many of the 100 million American adults who have obesity and alleviate a grave public health concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Peace, a Forgotten Word, Renews its Claim in the Holy Land
description: Long derided as naïve, even traitors, the bridge builders between Israelis and Palestinians sense opportunity in the aftermath of the Hamas attack.
content: Awad Darawshe, shot in the abdomen, bled to death under the stage at the trance music festival that Hamas gunmen transformed into a killing field. A Palestinian Israeli paramedic, he died in a desperate attempt to save the lives of Jews at the Tribe of Nova peace-and-love gathering that marked the Jewish holiday of Sukkot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Stories on Living Small, at Large
description: In a biweekly column for Real Estate, Julie Lasky and Tim McKeough dispense advice and profile people making the most of homes short on one key feature: square footage.
content: It was a sunny September morning when Julie Lasky, a contributor to The New York Times’s Real Estate section, was scoping out dog owners on a street in Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Tompkins Square Dog Parade Draws Thousands After Near-Cancellation
description: After almost being canceled because of financial constraints, about 15,000 people and more than 600 pups turned out for the annual parade on Saturday — nearly doubling last year’s attendance.
content: Despite the gray skies and light drizzle, costumed dogs strutted along for the Tompkins Square Halloween Dog Parade on Saturday as they have for more than three decades. But for the first time since the event’s inception, they had an official parade route.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Israel Strikes West Bank Mosque, Killing Two
description: The Israeli military carried out a rare airstrike in the occupied West Bank, hitting a mosque in the Jenin refugee camp. Palestinian officials called the attack a “dangerous escalation.”
content: The Israeli military carried out a rare airstrike on a mosque in the occupied West Bank overnight, killing at least two people in what Palestinian officials called a “dangerous escalation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Hulu, HBO and Apple TV+ Know What You’re Going Through at Work
description: Workplace shows, a hit genre of the streaming era, are homing in on a knotty question: Do you have to sacrifice personal happiness to excel at your job?
content: On a recent episode of Apple TV+’s “The Morning Show,” the television host Alex Levy is conducting a live television interview with a therapist when things take a turn toward the personal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: When the Thrill of Victory Felt Truly Thrilling
description: Michael MacCambridge’s “The Big Time” rewinds to the ’70s, when showy personalities and compelling rivalries turned sports into mass entertainment.
content: It’s silly, and arbitrary — and increasingly antique — to organize American history by decades. But also oddly satisfying, like sorting a junk drawer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: A Hospice Nurse on Embracing the Grace of Dying
description: Hadley Vlahos​, TikTok star and best-selling author​, wants us to let go of our fighting words​ about death.
content: Hadley Vlahos​, TikTok star and best-selling author​, wants us to let go of our fighting words​ about death.
source.name: The New York Times
